attribute_definition: Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submittor should include a one line description of the study.

If this is data the CCRCN curates, the study will be assigned a 128-bit universal unique identifier. Submittors should only include this if it already exists for the data. Otherwise CCRCN personel will generate this as part of the data ingestion process.
Study start date.
Study end date.
If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submittor should include a study title. If this is data the CCRCN is ingesting, this can be pulled from the metadata or source text.
If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submittor should include a one paragraph description of the study. If this is data the CCRCN is ingesting, this can be pulled from the metadata or source text.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.

If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submittor should include five to fifteen descriptive words or phrases describing the study. If this is data the CCRCN is ingesting, this can be pulled from the metadata or source. Keywords help build some search functionality into the databases.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Submitter's family name.
Submitter's first name, middle name, middle initial, or any other names.
Submitter's current institution.
Submitter's current email address.
Submitter's current mailing address.
Submitter's current phone number.
TRUE or FALSE indicating whether the author should be contacted as the corresponding author.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Agency name funding the research, spelled out, no acronyms.
Code used by the agency to track the project funding.
Any other user generated notes about the project funding.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.

Submittors can associate multiple bibtex style citations with the dataset. They can also include the same information by filling out following attributes in tabular form if more convinient thank Bibtex formatting.
Code indicating the type of publication the study originates from.
The names of the author separated by and.
The year of publication or, if unpublished, the year of creation.
The title of the work.
The journal or magazine the work was published in.
The volume of a journal or multi-volume book.
The "(issue) number" of a journal, magazine, or tech-report, if applicable. (Most publications have a "volume", but no "number" field.).
Page numbers, separated either by commas or double-hyphens.
Permanent web address where the work can be located.
Digital object identifier associated with the work.
Publisher's address (usually just the city, but can be the full address for lesser-known publishers).
An annotation for annotated bibliography styles (not typical).
The title of the book, if only part of it is being cited.
The chapter number.
The key of the cross-referenced entry.
The edition of a book, long form (such as "First" or "Second").
The name(s) of the editor(s).
How it was published, if the publishing method is nonstandard.
The institution that was involved in the publishing, but not necessarily the publisher.

A hidden field used for specifying or overriding the alphabetical order of entries (when the "author" and "editor" fields are missing). Note that this is very different from the key (mentioned just after this list) that is used to cite or cross-reference the entry.
The month of publication (or, if unpublished, the month of creation).
Miscellaneous extra information.
The conference sponsor.
The publisher's name.
The school where the thesis was written.
The series of books the book was published in (e.g. "The Hardy Boys" or "Lecture Notes in Computer Science").
The field overriding the default type of publication (e.g. "Research Note" for techreport, "{PhD} dissertation" for phdthesis, "Section" for inbook/incollection).
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Number of cores per study. This number can be automatically generated by ingestion code.
Code indicating what type of device was used to collect soil depth profiles.
Any notable comments on how the authors either included or excluded live roots from carbon assesments.
Any notable comments on whether or not sediment was sieved prior to carbon measurements.
If sediment was sieved, the size of sieve used.
Any notable codes regarding how the authors qualified or quantified compaction of the core.
Temperature at which samples were dried to measure dry bulk density. This can include either samples that were freeze dried or oven dried.
Time over which samples were dried to measure dry bulk density.
Any notable codes regarding how the authors quantified dry bulk density.
Temperature at which samples were combusted to estimate fraction organic matter.
Time over which samples were combusted to estimate fraction organic matter.
Any notable comments on how the authors estimated organic matter fraction using loss on ignition.
Code indicating whether fraction carbon was measured or estimated as a function of organic matter.
Whether or not carbonates were removed prior to calculating fraction organic carbon.
The method used to remove carbonates prior to measuring fraction carbon.
Any notable comments on how the authors measured fraction carbon.
Code indicating the method used for determining radiocesium activity.
Code indicating the method used for determining lead 210 activity.
Code indicating the mass or accretion rate used in the excess_pb_210_model
Code indicating the model used to estimate excess lead 210.
Code indicating the method used for determining radiocarbon activity.
Sample volume used for loss on ignition and bulk density measurements, if held constant.
Sample mass used for loss on ignition and bulk density measurements, if held constant.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Site identification code unique to each study.
Site description including relevant study details and political geographic units. Some of these descriptions can be automated by the ingestion code.
Maximum latitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Minimum latitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Maximum longitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Minimum longitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.

As an alternative to submitting or automatically generating a bounding box, submittors can include a shapefile (.shp) or keyhole markup language (.kml) documenting the geographic boundaries of the site. This can be converted to and stored in well known text (WTK) format.
Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating average annual salinity.
Indicate whether salinity_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement.
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how salinity_class was determined.
Code based on submitter field observations or measurement indicating dominant wetland vegetation type.
Indicate whether vegetation_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how vegetation_class was were determined
Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating how often the coring location is inundated
Indicate whether inundation_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how elevation was determined
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Site identification code unique to each study.
Core identification code unique to each site.
Date of core collection.
Any other relevant user generated notes on how cores were collected.
Positional latitude of the core in decimal degree WGS84.
Positional longitude of the core in decimal degree WGS84.
Accuracy of latitude and longitude measurement, if determined and recorded.
Code indicating how latitude and longitude were determined.
Any relevant user generated notes on how latitude and longitude were determined.
Surface elevation of the core relative to defined datum.
The datum relative to which the core was measured.
Accuracy of elevation measurement, if determined and recorded
Code indicating how elevationwas determined
Any relevant user generated notes on how elevation was determined
Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating average annual salinity.
Indicate whether salinity_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant user generated notes on how salinity_class was determined
Code based on submitter field observations or measurement indicating dominant wetland vegetation type.
Indicate whether salinity_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how vegetation_class and dominant_species were determined.
Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating how often the coring location is inundated.
Indicate whether inundation_classwas determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how elevation was determined
Indicated whether or not the coring team believes they recovered a full sediment profile, down to bedrock, or other non-marsh interface.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Code associated with a species or a vegetation assembelage.
Genus according to the most up to date classification.
Species according to the most up to date classification.
Any nomenclature referring to subspecies special cases.
Any nomenclature referring to special cases of hybridization.
Common name associated with the species, especially if it is referred to in any accompanying text.
Any other user submitted notes regarding the species.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author's family name, as well as the second author's or 'et al.' if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
Site identification code unique to each study
Core identification code unique to each site
Minimum depth of a sampling increment.
Maximum depth of a sampling increment.
Sample identification unique to the core. This should be used in the case that there are relevant lab specific sample codes, or in the case that there are multiple replicate samples.
Dry mass per unit volume of a soil sample. This does not include ash free bulk density.
Mass of organic matter relative to sample dry mass.  Ash free bulk density should not be used here but should be expressed as a loss on ignition fraction .
Mass of carbon relative to sample dry mass.
Code assigned to specify the type of measurement fraction_carbon represents.
Fraction of the sample depth interval reduced due to compaction.
Any user generated notes on compaction.
Radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for radiocesium (<sup>137</sup>Cs).
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with cs137_activity.
Any user generated notes on <sup>137</sup>Cs dating process.
Excess radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for excess lead 210 (<sup>210</sup>Pb).
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with excess_pb210_activity.
Any user generated notes on <sup>210</sup>Pb dating process.
Radiocarbon age as estimated from AMS measurements.
Estimated uncertainty in c14_age.
Description of the material selected for radiocarbon (<sup>14</sup>C) dating.
Any relevant user generated notes on <sup>14</sup>C dating process.
The isotopic signiture of <sup>13</sup>C. This is oftentimes measured along with c14_age and can be useful for analysing carbon lability and provenance.
Radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for <sup>241</sup>Am.
Estimated uncertainty in am_241_activity.
The age of any other dated depth horizon such as an artificial marker, pollen horizon, pollution horizon, etc.
Code indicating the type of marker.
Any other user generated notes about the origin of the marker.
